p: Many studies have determined the antimalarial activity of herbal extracts against the asexual disease-causing parasite using the standard 72-hour drug assay [ 14– 18], and their activity was classified as ‘good' (IC 50 < 10 μg/ml), ‘moderate' (IC 50 10 μg/ml to 50 μg/ml), ‘low' (IC 50 50 μg/ml to 100 μg/ml), and ‘inactive' (IC 50 > 100 μg/ml) based on the concentration of the product that causes a 50% reduction in parasite prevalence (IC 50) values [ 19]. The effects of a longer treatment regimen on both the asexual parasite and the gametocyte have more frequently been left undetermined. In this study, the short- and long-term effects of aqueous extracts of four selected herbal plants collected from the Western Region of Ghana on malaria parasite growth in vitro were determined using artemisinin-resistant IPC_4912, the artemisinin sensitive CamWT_C580Y and the chloroquine-sensitive NF54 P. falciparum parasites.
